commit_message:
Documentation about HDP plugin

Merging initial documentation changes for HDP plugin

Change-Id: Ie29c2aad292198a0e90ffdfce2d63eba153f793d
Fixes: bug #1204178
(cherry picked from commit b449390c167e4ccddc1aa3dc2ff6cec8c64924db)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/83/45583/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hortonworks Data Plaform Plugin =============================== The Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP) Savanna plugin provides a way to provision HDP clusters on OpenStack using templates in a single click and in an easily repeatable fashion. As seen from the architecture diagram below, the Savanna controller serves as the glue between Hadoop and OpenStack. The HDP plugin mediates between the Savanna controller and Apache Ambari in order to deploy and configure Hadoop on OpenStack. Core to the HDP Plugin is Apache Ambari that is used as the orchestrator for deploying the HDP stack on OpenStack. .. image:: ../images/hdp-plugin-architecture.png :width: 800 px :scale: 80 % :align: center The HDP plugin uses Ambari Blueprints aka templates for cluster provisioning. Apache Ambari Blueprints (aka Cluster templates) ================================================ Apache Ambari Blueprints is a portable document definition, which provides a complete definition for an Apache Hadoop cluster, including cluster topology, components, services and their configurations. Ambari Blueprints can be consumed by the HDP plugin to instantiate a Hadoop cluster on OpenStack. The benefits of this approach is that it allows for Hadoop clusters to be configured and deployed using an Ambari native format that can be used with as well as outside of OpenStack allowing for clusters to be re-instantiated in a variety of environments. For more information about Apache Ambari Blueprints, refer to: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMBARI-1783. Note that Apache Ambari Blueprints are not yet finalized. Operation ========= The HDP Plugin performs the following four primary functions during cluster creation: 1. Software deployment - the plugin orchestrates the deployment of the required software to the target VMs 2. Services Installation - the Hadoop services configured for the node groups within the cluster are installed on the associated VMs 3. Services Configuration - the plugin merges the default configuration values and user provided configurations for each installed service to the cluster 4. Services Start - the plugin invokes the appropriate APIs to indicate to the Ambari Server that the cluster services should be started Images ====== The Savanna HDP plugin can make use of either minimal (operating system only) images or pre-populated HDP images. The base requirement for both is that that the image is cloud-init enabled and contains a supported operating system (see http://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP1/HDP-1.2.4/bk_hdp1-system-admin-guide/content/sysadminguides_ha_chap2_3.html). The advantage of a pre-populated image is that provisioning time is accelerated, as packages do not need to be downloaded and installed which make up the majority of the time spent in the provisioning cycle. As with the provided pre-populated image, a pre-populated image can install any of the following packages: * hadoop-libhdfs * hadoop-native * hadoop-pipes * hadoop-sbin * hadoop-lzo * hadoop-lzo-native * mysql-server * httpd * net-snmp * net-snmp-utils * perl-Net-SNMP * nagios * fping * nagios-plugins * hdp_mon_nagios_addons * ganglia-gmetad * gweb hdp_mon_ganglia_addons * ganglia-gmond * python-rrdtool.x86_64 * glibc glibc.i686 * appropriate JDK satisfying Ambari requirement * epel-release Any packages that are not installed in a pre-populated image will automatically be installed during the HDP provisioning process. There are two VM images provided for use with the HDP Plugin: 1. `centos-6_64-hdp-1.3.qcow2 <http://public-repo-1.hortonworks.com/savanna/images/centos-6_4-64-hdp-1.3.qcow2>`_: This image contains most of the requisite packages necessary for HDP deployment. The packages contained herein correspond to the HDP 1.3 release. The operating system is a minimal CentOS 6.4 cloud-init enabled install. This image can only be used to provision HDP 1.3 hadoop clusters. 2. `centos-6-64-hdp-vanilla.qcow2 <http://public-repo-1.hortonworks.com/savanna/images/centos-6_4-64-vanilla.qcow2>`_: This image provides only a minimal install of CentOS 6.4 and is cloud-init enabled. This image can be used to provision any versions of HDP supported by Savanna. Please refer to the reference VM image provided for specific details. Limitations =========== The HDP plugin currently has the following limitations: * Currently, the HDP plugin provides support for HDP 1.3. Once HDP2 is released, support for this version will be provided. * Swift integration is not yet implemented. * It is not possible to decrement the number of node-groups or hosts per node group in a Savanna generated cluster. * Only the following services are available to be deployed via Savanna: * Ambari * Nagios * Ganglia * HDFS * MAPREDUCE Note: Other services may be added using Ambari after initial cluster creation. Cluster Validation ================== Prior to Hadoop cluster creation, the HDP plugin will perform the following validation checks to ensure a successful Hadoop deployment: * Ensure the existence of a NAMENODE process in the cluster * Ensure the existence of a JOBTRACKER should any TASKTRACKER be deployed to the cluster * Ensure the deployment of one Ambari Server instance to the cluster * Ensure that each defined node group had an associated Ambari Agent configured The HDP Plugin and Savanna Support ================================== A Hortonworks supported version of HDP OpenStack plugin will become available at a future date. For more information, please contact Hortonworks.

commit_message:
Add an OpenStack PyPI mirror element.

os-svc-install could use this, and we need to ensure that all things
installed from pip, not just os-svc-install tasks, get installed from
the OpenStack PyPI mirror for test runs.

Change-Id: I243a4dc34f3a2d60c4ce6886e9bb694e708a54ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/61/45561/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eu PYPIURL=http://pypi.openstack.org/openstack/ mkdir -p ~/.pip if [ -e ~/.pip/pip.conf ]; then mv ~/.pip/pip.conf{,.orig} fi if [ -e ~/.pydistutils.cfg ]; then mv ~/.pydistutils.cfg{,.orig} fi cat <<EOF > ~/.pip/pip.conf [global] index-url = $PYPIURL log = $HOME/pip.log EOF cat <<EOF > ~/.pydistutils.cfg [easy_install] index_url = $PYPIURL EOF

commit_message:
Drop deps on heat-cfntools.

We're meant to be using os-collect-config now, but rabbitmq-server and
nagios3 were sucking heat-cfntools in unintentionally. They should
never have depended on heat-cfntools, as it's dependencies were solely
on os-apply-config and os-refresh-config : the way those are invoked
is not their problem.

Change-Id: I3c8b92931055192a7b9220cdc5d66a2a444ae33f

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/28/44928/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hortonworks Data Plaform Plugin =============================== Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP) OpenStack plugin provides a way to provision HDP clusters on OpenStack using templates in a single click and in a easily repeatable fashion. As seen from the architecture diagram below, Savanna controller serves as the glue between Hadoop and OpenStack. It deals with calling the right underlying OpenStack projects to provision virtual machines, setup networking & configure storage. Once that is done, HDP plugin deals with interfacing with Hadoop and Ambari. Core to the HDP Plugin is Apache Ambari that is used as the orchestrator for deploying the HDP stack on OpenStack. .. image:: ../images/hdp-plugin-architecture.png :width: 800 px :scale: 99 % :align: center The HDP plugin uses Ambari Blueprints aka templates for cluster provisioning Ambari Blueprints (aka Cluster templates) ========================================= Ambari Blueprints is a portable document definition, which provides a complete definition for an Apache Hadoop cluster, including cluster topology, component, service and their configuration. Ambari Blueprints can be consumed by the HDP plugin to instantiate a Hadoop cluster on OpenStack. The benefits of this approach is that it allows for Hadoop clusters to be configured and deployed using an Ambari native format that can be used with as well as outside of OpenStack allowing for clusters to be re-instantiated in a variety of environments. For more information about Ambari Blueprints, refer to: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMBARI-1783. Note that Ambari Blueprints are not yet finalized. Operation ========= The HDP Plugin performs the following four primary functions during cluster creation: 1. Software deployment - the plugin orchestrates the deployment of the required software to the target VMs 2. Services Installation - the Hadoop services configured for the node groups within the cluster are installed on the associated VMs 3. Services Configuration - the plugin merges the default configuration values and user provided configurations for each installed service to the cluster 4. Services Start - the plugin invokes the appropriate APIs to indicate to the Ambari Server that the cluster services should be started Images ====== The Savanna HDP plugin can make use of either minimal (operating system only) images or pre-populated HDP images. The base requirement for both is that that the image is cloud-init enabled and contains a supported operating system (see http://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP1/HDP-1.2.4/bk_hdp1-system-admin-guide/content/sysadminguides_ha_chap2_3.html). The advantage of a pre-populated image is that provisioning time is accelerated, as packages do not need to be downloaded and installed which make up the majority of the time spent in the provisioning cycle. As with the provided pre-populated image, a pre-populated image can install any of the following packages: * hadoop-libhdfs * hadoop-native * hadoop-pipes * hadoop-sbin * hadoop-lzo * hadoop-lzo-native * mysql-server * httpd * net-snmp * net-snmp-utils * perl-Net-SNMP * nagios * fping * nagios-plugins * hdp_mon_nagios_addons * ganglia-gmetad * gweb hdp_mon_ganglia_addons * ganglia-gmond * python-rrdtool.x86_64 * glibc glibc.i686 * appropriate JDK satisfying Ambari requirement * epel-release Any packages that are not installed in a pre-populated image will automatically be installed during the HDP provisioning process. There are two VM images provided for use with the HDP Plugin: 1. `centos-6_64-hdp-1.3.qcow2 <http://https://s3.amazonaws.com/public-repo-1.hortonworks.com/savanna/images/centos-6_4-64-hdp-1.3.qcow2>`_: This image contains most of the requisite packages necessary for HDP deployment. The packages contained herein correspond to the HDP 1.3 release. The operating system is a minimal CentOS 6.4 cloud-init enabled install. This image can only be used to provision HDP 1.3 hadoop clusters. 2. `centos-6-64-hdp-vanilla.qcow2 <http://https://s3.amazonaws.com/public-repo-1.hortonworks.com/savanna/images/centos-6_4-64-vanilla.qcow2>`_: This image provides only a minimal install of CentOS 6.4 and is cloud-init enabled. This image can be used to provision any versions of HDP supported by Savanna. Please refer to the reference VM image provided for specific details. Limitations =========== The HDP plugin currently has the following limitations: * Currently, the HDP plugin provides support for HDP 1.3. Once HDP2 is released, support for this version will be provided. * Swift integration is not yet implemented. * It is not possible to decrement the number of node-groups or hosts per node group in a Savanna generated cluster. * Only the following services are available to be deployed via Savanna: * Ambari * Nagios * Ganglia * HDFS * MAPREDUCE Note: Other services may be added using Ambari after initial cluster creation. Cluster Validation ================== Prior to Hadoop cluster creation, the HDP plugin will perform the following validation checks to ensure a successful Hadoop deployment: * Ensure the existence of a NAMENODE process in the cluster * Ensure the existence of a JOBTRACKER should any TASKTRACKER be deployed to the cluster * Ensure the deployment of one Ambari Server instance to the cluster * Ensure that each defined node group had an associated Ambari Agent configured The HDP Plugin and Savanna Support ================================== A Hortonworks supported version of HDP OpenStack plugin will become available at a future date. For more information, please contact Hortonworks.

commit_message:
Change cfn-signal option --exit to --exit-code

According cfn user guide, the long option of cfn-signal -e should be
--exit-code.

Fixes bug #1220080

The nova::api class currently declares the cinder::client
class. Having this dependency set as a declaration leads

with other classes that also need to include the
cinder::client class (ie openstack::client).

commit_message:
Replace cinder::client class declaration with include

The nova::api class currently declares the cinder::client
class. Having this dependency set as a declaration leads
to issues when you try to combine the nova::api class
with other classes that also need to include the
cinder::client class (ie openstack::client).

This commit changes the declaration to an include to
ensure that this class can be combined with all other
classes without conflict.

Change-Id: I9c6604acfbde4c00629c9ab658f81b9444e85f7f
(cherry picked from commit 33996781540ef57ac0d3eb121845fa0eef372ed2)

commit_message:
Replace cinder::client class declaration with include

The nova::api class currently declares the cinder::client
class. Having this dependency set as a declaration leads
to issues when you try to combine the nova::api class
with other classes that also need to include the
cinder::client class (ie openstack::client).

This commit changes the declaration to an include to
ensure that this class can be combined with all other
classes without conflict.

Change-Id: I9c6604acfbde4c00629c9ab658f81b9444e85f7f

subject: Validate VV Set exists in 3PAR drivers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-04 22:16:11.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/san/hp/hp_3par_common.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/3a2db8e03434c3132d47a7256b9bd085662c5ca2', 'message': 'Validate VV Set exists in 3PAR drivers

The 3PAR drivers must first create a volume and then add that
volume to a virtual volume set on the backend for QoS support.
If that predefined virutal volume set does not exists the
volume would not be associated with the correct QoS settings.
This patch will now look to see if the virtaul volume set
exists and if not will delete the volume and notify the user
that the VV Set does not exists.

Change-Id: I460f6dd7001362b850c49454c78673aecd4cfef0
Fixes: bug 1218554
'}]
commit_message:
Validate VV Set exists in 3PAR drivers

The 3PAR drivers must first create a volume and then add that
volume to a virtual volume set on the backend for QoS support.
If that predefined virutal volume set does not exists the
volume would not be associated with the correct QoS settings.
This patch will now look to see if the virtaul volume set
exists and if not will delete the volume and notify the user
that the VV Set does not exists.

Change-Id: I460f6dd7001362b850c49454c78673aecd4cfef0
Fixes: bug 1218554

commit_message:
Remove unused/redundant methods in cinder/test.py

The following methods are not used anywhere in Cinder
- assertDictListMatch()
- assertSubDictMatch()

The following methods are implemented in testtools
- assertIn()
- assertNotIn()

Change-Id: Iea96f7761c33ac774b5b4ae71e544aa007ba1bb2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/13/45513/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def assertDictListMatch(self, L1, L2, approx_equal=False, tolerance=0.001): """Assert a list of dicts are equivalent.""" def raise_assertion(msg): L1str = str(L1) L2str = str(L2) base_msg = ('List of dictionaries do not match: %(msg)s ' 'L1: %(L1str)s L2: %(L2str)s' % {'msg': msg, 'L1str': L1str, 'L2str': L2str}) raise AssertionError(base_msg) L1count = len(L1) L2count = len(L2) if L1count != L2count: raise_assertion('Length mismatch: len(L1)=%(L1count)d != ' 'len(L2)=%(L2count)d' % {'L1count': L1count, 'L2count': L2count}) for d1, d2 in zip(L1, L2): self.assertDictMatch(d1, d2, approx_equal=approx_equal, tolerance=tolerance) def assertSubDictMatch(self, sub_dict, super_dict): """Assert a sub_dict is subset of super_dict.""" self.assertTrue(set(sub_dict.keys()).issubset(set(super_dict.keys()))) for k, sub_value in sub_dict.items(): super_value = super_dict[k] if isinstance(sub_value, dict): self.assertSubDictMatch(sub_value, super_value) elif 'DONTCARE' in (sub_value, super_value): continue else: self.assertEqual(sub_value, super_value) def assertIn(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs): """Python < v2.7 compatibility. Assert 'a' in 'b'""" try: f = super(TestCase, self).assertIn except AttributeError: self.assertTrue(a in b, *args, **kwargs) else: f(a, b, *args, **kwargs) def assertNotIn(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs): """Python < v2.7 compatibility. Assert 'a' NOT in 'b'""" try: f = super(TestCase, self).assertNotIn except AttributeError: self.assertFalse(a in b, *args, **kwargs) else: f(a, b, *args, **kwargs)

commit_message:
Synchronize extend_volume methods in 3PAR drivers

The extend_volume methods in the HP3PAR FC and
iSCSI drivers should have been synchronized with
the synchronize annotation, but were not.

Change-Id: Ic7f18b7314e10dfb499b16f43b72367fe3ed1176
Closes-Bug: #1220947
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/73/45273/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 1.2.1 - Synchronized extend_volume method. VERSION = "1.2.1" @utils.synchronized('3par', external=True)

commit_message:
Add support for LocalConnector type in brick

GPFS and other file based drivers require a LocalConnector to support
volume connection and migration operations.

Modify brick/initiator/connector.py to add LocalConnector class.

Modify test_brick_connector.py to extend test_factory to include LocalConnector
class.

Modify test_gpfs.py to include new migrate_volume test.

Modify test_utils.py to extend test_brick_get_connector to include LocalConnector
class.

Closes-Bug: #1218052

Change-Id: I259fae339c2df7ae304a91c80c27d135762041f5

commit_message:
Import modules from package

Add function import_modules_from_package into rally.utils
Use import_modules_from_package in deplog and vmprovide for load engines and providers

Change-Id: I42400db8cc8f1d8ba2a14f3195df71dc60cae036

commit_message:
Add auth plugins

Historically we had auth_system in novaclient used for Rackspace Cloud
key based auth system.

Using auth plugins in keystoneclient makes easy to add new auth
mechanisms in keystoneclient as well as in third-party libraries.
Auth plugins can be discovered dynamically using stevedore and
chosen by auth system name.

Implements: blueprint keystoneclient-auth-system

Change-Id: Ie98c4f1ef0c83263e39129d40c643596a7cd67d9

commit_message:
Expose ESXi host in hypervisor-list with vSphere Driver

(WORKINPROGRESS) - This is just a prototype, trying a few things out.

I'll follow up with email to dev list etc and start a BP when ready

Change-Id: I7fdadbf6e98fdcb7c6926c23528894ba2159e47b

subject: Allow backends to be modules/objects instead of strings
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-07 02:34:49.000000000', 'files': ['taskflow/storage.py', 'taskflow/persistence/logbook.py', 'taskflow/persistence/backends/memory/api.py', 'taskflow/tests/unit/persistence/test_memory_persistence.py', 'taskflow/persistence/flowdetail.py', 'taskflow/persistence/taskdetail.py', 'taskflow/tests/unit/persistence/test_sql_persistence.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/3e75f2291978318155c1cd74a98807e40f876425', 'message': "Allow backends to be modules/objects instead of strings

Instead of forcing a logbook creator to provide a backend
that is a string, allow for the logbook backend to be an
arbitary module/object that implements the backend api.

This is useful so that users of logbooks can easily alter
and change the backend that will store logbooks without
having to go through the registration process that exists
currently in the backend api (they can still use this if
they desire).

Also fixes a bug where when a module was given to the logbook
and in the memory backend a deep copy would be performed which
would then start to deep copy the memory api backend itself,
which would fail since the memory backend contains locks which
can not be deep copied. Remove that deep copying since it really
isn't useful to perform (and the memory backend is mainly for
testing purposes anyway).

Change-Id: I14624806f3d6cbe5347bc590078ce506be64a180
"}]
commit_message:
Allow backends to be modules/objects instead of strings

Instead of forcing a logbook creator to provide a backend
that is a string, allow for the logbook backend to be an
arbitary module/object that implements the backend api.

This is useful so that users of logbooks can easily alter
and change the backend that will store logbooks without
having to go through the registration process that exists
currently in the backend api (they can still use this if
they desire).

Also fixes a bug where when a module was given to the logbook
and in the memory backend a deep copy would be performed which
would then start to deep copy the memory api backend itself,
which would fail since the memory backend contains locks which
can not be deep copied. Remove that deep copying since it really
isn't useful to perform (and the memory backend is mainly for
testing purposes anyway).

Change-Id: I14624806f3d6cbe5347bc590078ce506be64a180

commit_message:
Allow provides to be a set and results to be a dictionary

Instead of forcing task provides to be a tuple or list and
using the corresponding numerical index to determine how to
interpret the tasks results we should also allow for the task
provides to be a set and then allow for the tasks result to be
interpreted as a dictionary.

Fixes bug 1221998

Change-Id: Ibae689e7975d6782aa248d2b6e3691c44a89ef9f

commit_message:
Temporary fix agent-compute dpkg bug 1221945

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/cloud-archive/+bug/1221945
The ubuntu cloud archive ceilometer-agent-compute pkg has a bug in which init
script isn't installing properly gets installed as:
/etc/init/ceilometer-agent.conf.dpk-new therefore until it gets fixed this temp
solution works

Change-Id: I0f017c834e23fb731e5ca57fb9ab90826072c1cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-telemetry refs/changes/92/45492/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # temp fix for compute-agent init not installing properly ubuntu if node[:platform] == "ubuntu" init_script = "/etc/init/ceilometer-agent-compute.conf" execute "fix init script" do command "cp #{init_script}.dpkg-new #{init_script}" not_if { ::File.exists?(init_script) } end end

commit_message:
Allow engines to be copied + blacklist broken flows

Allow engines to be copied to integrated projects via
update.py and for the time being blacklist threaded and
graph flow from being copied (to avoid breakage) until
the bugs associated with fixing those flows are fixed.

Also a bug was found that would not allow copying over
the utils module (since a utils.py file no longer
exists) so ensure that when we encounter a module (and
not a .py file) we can copy over the correct file that
belongs to that module (in the case of utils this would
be the __init__.py of the utils folder).

Also fixes a bug where it appears that due to our usage
of defaultdict we would copy over more modules than
desired due to how 'reading' a key in a defaultdict
actually creates that key using the default value which
caused these extra module inclusions.

Change-Id: I2aa732fc0baf269ee87aa72bfe8495e51ad21faf

commit_message:
Set a small max_template_size for test_long_yaml

Currently this test takes 22 seconds to run. As the intent
of the test seems to be to assert that limits are enforced,
this change reduces the default limit to speed test execution time.

Change-Id: Ie12c53b832c993711c2187004d015b65045da901
Fixes-Bug: #1221478

commit_message:
Only validate credentials on create based on resources

This change relaxes the validation which checked for credentials
on stack create and update.

As implemented, having any of the following resources
in the template will result in credentials being mandatory
on create and update:
* AWS::AutoScaling::ScalingPolicy
* OS::Heat::HARestarter
* AWS::CloudFormation::WaitConditionHandle

For all other templates, credentials are not needed.

When trusts are merged, this logic could also be used to decide
whether a trust token needs to be created at all.

Fixes bug: #1217617

Change-Id: I3e4b8698d3712053dc3c0851433ef0cbbadbdfed

commit_message:
Adjust validate.py for flattened directory structure

With this change validate.py validates and builds again the manuals.

I disabled validation of basic-install-pom.xml as it's a pom.xml
file.
Currently the basic-install guide is not build at all.

Change-Id: Ib6258486877628a713a5bb4ac8ea53290d6d8300

commit_message:
Flesh out LBaaS Workflow example

Add info on how to find subnet ID, available options
for flags used and some optional flags I feel are important
(--connection-limit and --session-persistence).

Also made some formatting changes to improve readablity.

Change-Id: I35e1d441c5eb4db3db49c520c8f1167e7348d7a5
Closes-Bug: #1221739
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/51/45451/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Find the correct subnet ID. The load balancer virtual IP (vip) and the instances that provide the balanced service must all be on the same subnet. The first step then is to obtain a list of available subnets and their IDs: neutron subnet-list Create a load balancer pool using the appropriate subnet ID from the list obtained above: Valid options for --lb-method depend on the backend provider. For the reference implementation based on HAProxy valid options are: ROUND_ROBIN, LEAST_CONNECTIONS, or SOURCE_IP Valid options for protocol are: HTTP, HTTPS, or TCP Associate servers with pool: Optionally --weight may be specified as an integer in the range 0..256. The weight of a member determines the portion of requests or connections it services compared to the other members of the pool. A value of 0 means the member will not participate in load-balancing but will still accept persistent connections. Create a health monitor which checks to make sure our instances are still running on the specified protocol-port: Valid options for --type are: PING, TCP, HTTP, HTTPS. It is also possible to set --url_path which defaults to "/" and if specified must begin with a leading slash Associate health monitor with pool: Create a Virtual IP Address (VIP) that when accessed via the load balancer will direct the requests to one of the pool members: Values for --protocol here are these same as in the pool creation step above. Connection rate limiting can be implemented using the --connection-limit flag and specifying maximum connections per second. As written above the load balancer will not have persistent sessions, to define persistent sessions so that a given client will always connect to the same backend (so long as it is still operational) use the following form: neutron lb-vip-create --name myvip --protocol-port 80 --protocol HTTP --subnet-id <subnet-uuid> --session-persistence type=dict type=<type>,[cookie_name=<name>] mypool Valid session persistence types are: APP_COOKIE, HTTP_COOKIE or SOURCE_IP. The APP_COOKIE type reuses a cookie from your application to manage persistence and requires the additional option cookie_name=<name> to inform the load balancer of which cookie name to use, this cookie_name is unused with other persistence types.

subject: Fix IF checks on spawned green thread instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-06 01:50:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e806e44d0893039b5e36b7d8cbedd8147e2ad3b9', 'message': 'Fix for bug 1221486

Initially the symptom looks like race condition between two threads when stopping the task manager. After further analysis/troubleshooting, it turns out that two threads are spawned if a task manager is stopped and started again, causing unexpected errors.

The if check on the spawned thread is always false making the start() method thinks no thread has been started. Change the check to compare against None.

Also fixed a problme in unit-test where a thread may never terminated when a stop call is invoked during db access.

Closes-Bug: 1221486
Change-Id: I0d67bfe8fef7a390f0d6bc0f5a42835f86a9fb27

commit_message:
Fix IF checks on spawned green thread instance

Initially the symptom looks like race condition between two threads when
stopping the task manager. After further analysis/troubleshooting, it
turns out that two threads are spawned if a task manager is stopped and
started again, causing unexpected errors.

The IF check on the spawned thread sometimes return True sometime return False
if not compared against None explicitly. This makes start() method
think no thread has been started or stop() method think no thread is started.
Change the check to compare against None.

Also fixed a problem in unit-test where a thread may never terminated when
a stop call is invoked during db access.

Closes-Bug: 1221486
Change-Id: I0d67bfe8fef7a390f0d6bc0f5a42835f86a9fb27

commit_message:
Create Router on network topology fails

- just wrong definition of urls, missing '
- also add '{% load url from 'future' %} to maintain Django 1.4
  compatibility

Fixes bug 1219078

Change-Id: I661ab0561bab24c1af864a7fbd0e6913f6dfed06

VPNaaS UI implementation

This is an implementation of VPNaaS UI.

implements blueprint vpnaas-ui.

commit_message:
Utilize assertIsInstance

Using assertTrue and the 'isinstance' function to test
if an object is in an instance of some class is too python2.4.
Our unit testing framework supports assertIsInstance which was created
for these types of tests. Let's use assertIsInstance for these tests.

Change-Id: I2c931a52ae20f072f53210bf3dedb47127b413c0

self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.created_at.type, sqlalchemy.types.DATETIME)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.updated_at.type, sqlalchemy.types.DATETIME)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.deleted_at.type, sqlalchemy.types.DATETIME)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.deleted.type, sqlalchemy.types.BOOLEAN)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.deleted.type, sqlalchemy.types.BOOLEAN)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.id.type, sqlalchemy.types.INTEGER)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.volume_id.type, sqlalchemy.types.VARCHAR)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.key.type, sqlalchemy.types.VARCHAR)) self.assertTrue(isinstance(volume_admin_metadata.c.value.type, sqlalchemy.types.VARCHAR))

commit_message:
Merge with Oslo

Update modules to a117358d4215ad5ccbc378107f69966abe14bb2a
which includes the following commits:

    3198881 Add common methods required to allow translation
            of REST API responses
    df3f2ba BaseException.message is deprecated since Python 2.6
    79ee367 Add more robust gettext interpolation handling
    45e0cbe python3: Add basic python3 compatibility.
    1a2df89 Enable H302 hacking check
    d28fa69 python3: Add python3 compatibility.
    67bd769 python3: Fix traceback while running python3.
    b0c51ec Refactors to_bytes
    472d8ed Add slugify to strutils
    7119e29 Enable hacking H404 test.
    4246ce0 Added common code into fileutils and strutils.
    e3545f8 Enable hacking H402 test
    484a1df Enable hacking H403 test
    50cae76 Add basic lazy gettext implementation

Change-Id: I274b9111fe1d7de0c2585d96b90608732f80cc18

added_lines: # Copyright 2013 IBM Corp.import copyimport logging.handlersimport UserString import six """ Lazy gettext functionality. The following is an attempt to introduce a deferred way to do translations on messages in OpenStack. We attempt to override the standard _() function and % (format string) operation to build Message objects that can later be translated when we have more information. Also included is an example LogHandler that translates Messages to an associated locale, effectively allowing many logs, each with their own locale. """ def get_lazy_gettext(domain): """Assemble and return a lazy gettext function for a given domain. Factory method for a project/module to get a lazy gettext function for its own translation domain (i.e. nova, glance, cinder, etc.) """ def _lazy_gettext(msg): """Create and return a Message object. Message encapsulates a string so that we can translate it later when needed. """ return Message(msg, domain) return _lazy_gettext class Message(UserString.UserString, object): """Class used to encapsulate translatable messages.""" def __init__(self, msg, domain): # _msg is the gettext msgid and should never change self._msg = msg self._left_extra_msg = '' self._right_extra_msg = '' self.params = None self.locale = None self.domain = domain @property def data(self): # NOTE(mrodden): this should always resolve to a unicode string # that best represents the state of the message currently localedir = os.environ.get(self.domain.upper() + '_LOCALEDIR') if self.locale: lang = gettext.translation(self.domain, localedir=localedir, languages=[self.locale], fallback=True) else: # use system locale for translations lang = gettext.translation(self.domain, localedir=localedir, fallback=True) full_msg = (self._left_extra_msg + lang.ugettext(self._msg) + self._right_extra_msg) if self.params is not None: full_msg = full_msg % self.params return six.text_type(full_msg) def _save_parameters(self, other): # we check for None later to see if # we actually have parameters to inject, # so encapsulate if our parameter is actually None if other is None: self.params = (other, ) else: self.params = copy.deepcopy(other) return self # overrides to be more string-like def __unicode__(self): return self.data def __str__(self): return self.data.encode('utf-8') def __getstate__(self): to_copy = ['_msg', '_right_extra_msg', '_left_extra_msg', 'domain', 'params', 'locale'] new_dict = self.__dict__.fromkeys(to_copy) for attr in to_copy: new_dict[attr] = copy.deepcopy(self.__dict__[attr]) return new_dict def __setstate__(self, state): for (k, v) in state.items(): setattr(self, k, v) # operator overloads def __add__(self, other): copied = copy.deepcopy(self) copied._right_extra_msg += other.__str__() return copied def __radd__(self, other): copied = copy.deepcopy(self) copied._left_extra_msg += other.__str__() return copied def __mod__(self, other): # do a format string to catch and raise # any possible KeyErrors from missing parameters self.data % other copied = copy.deepcopy(self) return copied._save_parameters(other) def __mul__(self, other): return self.data * other def __rmul__(self, other): return other * self.data def __getitem__(self, key): return self.data[key] def __getslice__(self, start, end): return self.data.__getslice__(start, end) def __getattribute__(self, name): # NOTE(mrodden): handle lossy operations that we can't deal with yet # These override the UserString implementation, since UserString # uses our __class__ attribute to try and build a new message # after running the inner data string through the operation. # At that point, we have lost the gettext message id and can just # safely resolve to a string instead. ops = ['capitalize', 'center', 'decode', 'encode', 'expandtabs', 'ljust', 'lstrip', 'replace', 'rjust', 'rstrip', 'strip', 'swapcase', 'title', 'translate', 'upper', 'zfill'] if name in ops: return getattr(self.data, name) else: return UserString.UserString.__getattribute__(self, name) class LocaleHandler(logging.Handler): """Handler that can have a locale associated to translate Messages. A quick example of how to utilize the Message class above. LocaleHandler takes a locale and a target logging.Handler object to forward LogRecord objects to after translating the internal Message. """ def __init__(self, locale, target): """Initialize a LocaleHandler :param locale: locale to use for translating messages :param target: logging.Handler object to forward LogRecord objects to after translation """ logging.Handler.__init__(self) self.locale = locale self.target = target def emit(self, record): if isinstance(record.msg, Message): # set the locale and resolve to a string record.msg.locale = self.locale self.target.emit(record)

commit_message:
Merge with Oslo-incubator (2548344)

This merges rpc/ from Oslo-incubator, which includes the following
changs:

    bec54ac  Fix case error in qpid exchange type "direct"
    61c4cde  Ensure context type is handled when using to_dict
    223f9e1  Clarify precedence of secret_key_file
    a035f95  Don't shadow cfg import in securemessage
    0f88575  Remove redundant global keyword in securemessage
    848c4d5  Some nitpicky securemessage cleanups
    5c71c25  Allow non-use of cfg.CONF in securemessage
    9157286  RPC: Add MessageSecurity implementation
    2031e60  Refactors boolean returns
    34a6842  On reconnecting a FanoutConsumer, don't grow the topic name
    f52446c  Add serializer param to RPC service
    5ff534d  Add config for amqp durable/auto_delete queues
    f9f1b4f  Revert "Add support for heartbeating in the kombu RPC driver"
    7bfd443  Avoid shadowing Exception 'message' attribute
    c37f6aa  Add support for heartbeating in the kombu RPC driver

Change-Id: Iabc814147b359e810548b7ac906d4e1c52a20df3

commit_message:
Utilizes assertIsNotNone

Using assertTrue and the 'is not' operator to test if an element
is not None is too python2.4. Our unit testing framework supports
assertIsNotNone, included from python 2.7, which was created
for these types of tests.

Change-Id: I25c3f2b144357a3f86625deb8e324d78c20b9ce4

commit_message:
Remove deprecated assert_() usage

The method assert_() is an alias of assertTrue() and
is deprecated since python 2.7

http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#deprecated-aliases

This removes all assert_() uses.

Change-Id: I9f55c442cc2416a7aa2dac569d1750f723d95184

commit_message:
fix inconsistent i18n log message

An inconsistent example:
    imessage = _("Invalid metadata") + ": %(reason)s"
This is not consistent i18n usage. In most of cases, we use _() for
whole string instead of leaving something out.

More than inconsistent, some text in leaving strings may be not
translated, for example, ':' in English is different '' in Chinese.

Change-Id: I00e690021c44f1debbe034cc0837a07b292ffd1b
Closes-Bug: #1220813

commit_message:
Add metering panel to admin console

Now it has usage tables for disk usage,
network traffic usage, network(neutron) usage,
objectstore usage, all agregates of project.

A multiseries linechart with choosable meters, group by, value and time
span.

TODO
Tests fully implemented over all resource usage tabs.

Implements: blueprint admin-resource-usage-page
Change-Id: I9e6c2d25c2587a7642271e43109bc67e2ea1726f

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2012 Canonical Ltd. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import operator from django.utils.translation import ugettext_lazy as _ from django.core.context_processors import csrf from horizon import tabs from openstack_dashboard.api import ceilometer from .tables import GlobalDiskUsageTable from .tables import GlobalNetworkTrafficUsageTable from .tables import GlobalObjectStoreUsageTable from .tables import GlobalNetworkUsageTable class GlobalDiskUsageTab(tabs.TableTab): table_classes = (GlobalDiskUsageTable,) name = _("Global Disk Usage") slug = "global_disk_usage" template_name = ("horizon/common/_detail_table.html") def get_global_disk_usage_data(self): request = self.tab_group.request result = sorted(ceilometer.global_disk_usage(request), key=operator.itemgetter('tenant', 'user')) return result class GlobalNetworkTrafficUsageTab(tabs.TableTab): table_classes = (GlobalNetworkTrafficUsageTable,) name = _("Global Network Traffic Usage") slug = "global_network_traffic_usage" template_name = ("horizon/common/_detail_table.html") def get_global_network_traffic_usage_data(self): request = self.tab_group.request result = sorted(ceilometer.global_network_traffic_usage(request), key=operator.itemgetter('tenant', 'user')) return result class GlobalNetworkUsageTab(tabs.TableTab): table_classes = (GlobalNetworkUsageTable,) name = _("Global Network Usage") slug = "global_network_usage" template_name = ("horizon/common/_detail_table.html") def get_global_network_usage_data(self): request = self.tab_group.request result = sorted(ceilometer.global_network_usage(request), key=operator.itemgetter('tenant', 'user')) return result def allowed(self, request): permissions = ("openstack.services.network",) return request.user.has_perms(permissions) class GlobalObjectStoreUsageTab(tabs.TableTab): table_classes = (GlobalObjectStoreUsageTable,) name = _("Global Object Store Usage") slug = "global_object_store_usage" template_name = ("horizon/common/_detail_table.html") def get_global_object_store_usage_data(self): request = self.tab_group.request result = sorted(ceilometer.global_object_store_usage(request), key=operator.itemgetter('tenant', 'user')) return result def allowed(self, request): permissions = ("openstack.services.object-store",) return request.user.has_perms(permissions) class GlobalStatsTab(tabs.Tab): name = _("Stats") slug = "stats" template_name = ("admin/metering/stats.html") def get_context_data(self, request): meters = ceilometer.meter_list(self.request) # Remove gauge type data. meters = filter(lambda m: m.type == "cumulative", meters) # Remove meters with the same name. cached_meter_names = [] cached_meters = [] for m in meters: if m.name not in cached_meter_names: cached_meter_names.append(m.name) cached_meters.append(m) context = { 'meters': meters, 'meters_unique_names': cached_meters, } context.update(csrf(request)) return context class CeilometerOverviewTabs(tabs.TabGroup): slug = "ceilometer_overview" tabs = (GlobalDiskUsageTab, GlobalNetworkTrafficUsageTab, GlobalNetworkUsageTab, GlobalObjectStoreUsageTab, GlobalStatsTab,) sticky = True

commit_message:
blueprint : cloudbyte-elastistor-iscsi-driver

Change-Id: I9549a4001999b21494bab0abc298e03deaeee585
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/36/44436/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- import base64 import httplib import json import random import socket import string import uuid import hashlib from cinder import exception from cinder import flags from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder.volume.drivers.san.san import SanISCSIDriver from oslo.config import cfg VERSION = '1.0' LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) cb_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('cb_apikey', default='', help='API key to access CloudByte APIs'), cfg.StrOpt('cb_accountid', default='', help='CloudByte account under which storage volumes have to be created.'), ] FLAGS = flags.FLAGS FLAGS.register_opts(cb_opts) # Core class which implemented all the required functionalities class ElastistorISCSIDriver(SanISCSIDriver): FAILURE_MESSAGE =_("Failed to process request") # Default values for the properties to be sent to # CloudByte for API calls. DEFAULT_IOPS = 100 LATENCY=15 BLOCKSIZE=4 GRACEALLOWED="false" COMPRESSION="off" DEDUPLICATION="off" NOOFCOPIES=1 RECORDSIZE="128k" SYNC="standard" UNICODE="off" FCENABLED="false" ISCSIENABLED="true" IOPSCONTROL="true" TPCONTROL="true" MEMLIMIT="0" NETWORKSPEED="0" CASESENSITIVITY="sensitive" READONLY="off" volume_stats = {} def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ElastistorISCSIDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) # creates a volume in Elastistore def create_volume(self, volume): iops=ElastistorISCSIDriver.DEFAULT_IOPS latency=ElastistorISCSIDriver.LATENCY blocksize=ElastistorISCSIDriver.BLOCKSIZE account_name=None tsm_name=None # Retrieve params from volume metadata required # to create ElastiStor storage volume. for i in volume.get('volume_metadata'): if i.key == "iops": iops = i.value if i.key == "latency": latency = i.value if i.key == "blocksize": blocksize = i.value if i.key == "account_name": account_name = i.value if i.key == "tsm_name": tsm_name = i.value volume_name=self._generate_volume_name(volume["id"]) if account_name==None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: ElastiStor Account is required to create storage volume")) if tsm_name==None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: ElastiStor TSM is required to create storage volume")) # Fetch the api key from ElastiStor if it is not defined in the conf file. This is required to # communicate with ElastiStor. if FLAGS.cb_apikey == '': # 1. Login Request # cmd = self._send_login_request(FLAGS.san_login, FLAGS.san_password) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to login to ElastiStor")) self.apikey = cmd.apikey else: self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey # 2. Make a request to ElastiStor to get the account id from account name. # # account_id=self._get_elastistor_accountid(account_name) if account_id==None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to get Account details for the given Account name")) # #3. Make a request to ElastiStor to get Tsm details # throughput=int(blocksize)*int(iops) self._get_tsm_details(volume, volume_name, tsm_name, account_id, iops, blocksize,throughput) # #4. Make a request to ElastiStor to create a storage volume # self._create_elastistor_volume(account_name, account_id, volume,volume_name, iops, blocksize, latency, throughput) model_update={} model_update['provider_location'] = ('%s %s %s' % (self.iscsi_portal, self.iqn, 0)) model_update['provider_auth'] = ('CHAP %s %s' % (None, None)) return model_update # Deletes the volume def delete_volume(self, volume, is_snapshot=False): """ Delete CloudByte Volume from device. """ self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey volume_name=self._generate_volume_name(volume['id']) try: cmd=self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) self.volid=cmd.volumeid self._do_delete() except: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to delete volume in Elastistor")) return false def create_snapshot(self, snapshot_ref): self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey volume_name=self._generate_volume_name(snapshot_ref['volume_id']) volume_details=self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) if not volume_details.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to fetch storage volume in ElastiStor")) params={ "id":volume_details.volumeid, "name":snapshot_ref['display_name'] } createsnapshotCmd=CBCreateStorageSnapshot(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) createsnapshotCmd.execute() if not createsnapshotCmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to create snapshot in ElastiStor")) def delete_snapshot(self,snapshot_ref): self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey volume_name=self._generate_volume_name(snapshot_ref['volume_id']) volume_details=self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) if not volume_details.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to fetch storage volume in ElastiStor")) params={ "id":volume_details.volumeid } listsnapshots=CBListSnapshotsCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) listsnapshots.execute() if not listsnapshots.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to fetch snapshots for a volume in ElastiStor")) for i in listsnapshots.snapshots: if str(i.get("name"))==snapshot_ref["display_name"]: path=i.get("path") params={ "id":volume_details.volumeid, "path":path, } deletesnapshot=CBDeleteSnapshotCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) deletesnapshot.execute() if not deletesnapshot.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("ERROR: Failed to delete snapshot in ElastiStor")) def get_volume_stats(self, refresh=False): """Get volume status. If 'refresh' is True, run update first. The name is a bit misleading as the majority of the data here is cluster data """ if refresh: self._update_volume_status() return self.volume_stats def _update_volume_status(self): """Retrieve status info for the volume. TODO: Need to update other stats """ LOG.debug(_("Updating volume status info...")) data = {} data["vendor_name"] = 'CloudByte Inc' data["driver_version"] = VERSION data["storage_protocol"] = 'iSCSI' self.volume_stats = data def _create_elastistor_volume(self, account_name, account_id, volume, volume_name, iops, blocksize, latency,throughput): mount_name=str(account_name)+str(volume_name) cmd = self._send_add_qos_group_request(volume_name,mount_name,iops,volume['size'],blocksize,latency,throughput) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to add QoS group in ElastiStor")) self.qosid=cmd.qosid cmd = self._send_add_volume2_request(volume_name, volume['size'], account_id, mount_name) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to process add_volume2 request")) self.storageid=cmd.storageid cmd = self._send_add_volume_iscsi_service_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to process add_volume_iscsi_service request")) self.viscsiid=cmd.viscsiid cmd = self._send_update_controller_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to process update_controller request")) cmd = self._send_update_controller_storage_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to process update_controller_storage request")) cmd = self._send_update_controller_viscsiid() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to process update_controller_viscsiid request")) def _do_delete(self): params={} params["id"]=self.volid deleteCmd=CBDeleteFileSystem(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) deleteCmd.execute() #Generates the volume_name using volumeid def _generate_volume_name(self,id): volume_name="vol" tokens=id.split("-") for i in tokens: volume_name=volume_name+i return volume_name # Lists Accounts in Elastistore def _get_elastistor_accountid(self,account_name): params={ "page":"1", "pagesize":"20" } cmd=CBListAccount2Command(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) cmd.execute() accounts=cmd.accountlist account_id=None for account in accounts : if account.get("name")==account_name : account_id=account.get("id") return account_id # Fetches the details of TSM def _get_tsm_details(self, volume, volume_name, tsm_name, account_id, iops, blocksize,throughput): cmd = self._send_list_tsm_request(iops, volume['size'],account_id,throughput) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to fetch ElastiStor TSMs")) found=False for i in cmd.tsms: if str(i.get("name")) == str(tsm_name): found=True self.datasetid=str(i.get("datasetid")) self.tsmid=str(i.get("id")) self.poolid=str(i.get("poolid")) self.iqn_prefix=str(i.get("iqnname")) self.iqn=str(self.iqn_prefix)+':' + volume_name self.iscsi_portal=str(i.get("ipaddress"))+':3260' if not found: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to get TSM details for the given TSM name")) def _send_login_request(self, uname, passwd): encrypted_passwd = hashlib.md5(passwd).hexdigest() params = { "username": uname, "password": encrypted_passwd } loginCmd = CBLoginCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, params) loginCmd.execute() return loginCmd def _send_list_tsm_request(self, iops, size,account_id, throughput): size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" params = { "accountid": account_id, "iopsvalue": iops, "throughputvalue": throughput, "quotaSize": quotaSize } tsmCmd = CBListTsmCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) tsmCmd.execute() return tsmCmd def _send_add_qos_group_request(self, volume_name, mountname, iops,size, blocksize, latency, throughput): qosGroupName='QoS_'+volume_name size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" params={ "blocksize":blocksize, "datasetid":self.datasetid, "datasetname":volume_name, "graceallowed":ElastistorISCSIDriver.GRACEALLOWED, "iopscontrol":ElastistorISCSIDriver.IOPSCONTROL, "iops":iops, "latency":latency, "memlimit":ElastistorISCSIDriver.MEMLIMIT, "mountpoint":mountname, "name":qosGroupName, "networkspeed":ElastistorISCSIDriver.NETWORKSPEED, "protocoltype":"ISCSI", "quotasize":quotaSize, "throughput":throughput, "tpcontrol":ElastistorISCSIDriver.TPCONTROL, "tsmid":self.tsmid } qosCmd=CBAddQosGroupCommand(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) qosCmd.execute() return qosCmd def _send_add_volume2_request(self, volume_name, size, accountid, mountname): size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" mountname = volume_name params={"accountid":accountid, "tsmid":self.tsmid, "casesensitivity":ElastistorISCSIDriver.CASESENSITIVITY, "compression":ElastistorISCSIDriver.COMPRESSION, "datasetid":self.datasetid, "deduplication":ElastistorISCSIDriver.DEDUPLICATION, "fcenabled":ElastistorISCSIDriver.FCENABLED, "iscsienabled":ElastistorISCSIDriver.ISCSIENABLED, "mountpoint":mountname, "name":volume_name, "noofcopies":ElastistorISCSIDriver.NOOFCOPIES, "poolid":self.poolid, "qosgroupid":self.qosid, "quotasize":quotaSize, "readonly":ElastistorISCSIDriver.READONLY, "recordsize":ElastistorISCSIDriver.RECORDSIZE, "sync":ElastistorISCSIDriver.SYNC, "type":"volume", "unicode":ElastistorISCSIDriver.UNICODE, } volume2Cmd=CBAddVolume2Command(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) #jagani volume2Cmd.execute() return volume2Cmd def _send_add_volume_iscsi_service_request(self): params={"volumeid":self.storageid, "status":"true" } iscsiCmd=CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) iscsiCmd.execute() return iscsiCmd def _send_update_controller_request(self): params={"type":"qosgroup", "qosid":self.qosid, "tsmid":self.tsmid } controllerCmd=CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) controllerCmd.execute() return controllerCmd def _send_update_controller_storage_request(self): params={"storageid":self.storageid, "type":"storage", "tsmid":self.tsmid } storageCmd=CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) storageCmd.execute() return storageCmd def _send_update_controller_viscsiid(self): params={"viscsiid":self.viscsiid, "type":"configurevolumeiscsi" } viscsiCmd=CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) viscsiCmd.execute() return viscsiCmd def _send_update_qos_group(self, iops, qosid): params={"iops":iops,"latency":latency,"graceallowed":ElastistorISCSIDriver.GRACEALLOWED,"id":qosid} qosupdateCmd=CBUpdateQosGroup(FLAGS.san_ip,self.apikey,params) qosupdateCmd.execute() return qosupdateCmd def _send_list_file_system(self, volume_name): params={"page":"1","pagesize":"20"} listfilesystemCmd=CBListFileSystem(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params, volume_name) listfilesystemCmd.execute() return listfilesystemCmd # Base class for command classes class CBCommand(object): # Static variables # METHOD_GET = "GET" METHOD_POST = "POST" API_PREFIX = "/client/api?" PARAM_COMMAND = "command=" PARAM_APIKEY = "&apiKey=" URI_SEPARATOR = '&' STATUS_SUCCESS = 1 STATUS_FAILURE = 0 def __init__(self, ipaddr, cmd, apikey): LOG.debug(_("Initialize CloudByte command %s"), cmd) self.method = CBCommand.METHOD_GET self.command = cmd self.ipaddress = ipaddr self.apikey = apikey # # params hold all the attributes that need to be # passed as part of the request. In case of GET request, # params will be part of the URL. # self.request_params = {"response": "json"} def execute(self): LOG.debug(_("Executing command: %s"), self.command) connection = httplib.HTTPSConnection(self.ipaddress) uri = self._generate_uri() connection.request(self.method, uri) self.response = connection.getresponse() LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte response message :%s"),self.response.msg) LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte response status :%s"),self.response.status) LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte connection uri :%s"),uri) # TODO check for http error data = {} self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE if self.response.status == 200: self.json_response = json.load(self.response) self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS self.successCb() else: self.failureCb() def set_request_params(self, params): self.request_params.update(params) def set_method(self, m): self.method = m def print_request_params(self): LOG.debug(_("Printing command parameters")) for key in self.request_params: LOG.debug("Param: %s value: %s" % (key, self.request_params[key])) def _generate_uri(self): uri = CBCommand.API_PREFIX + CBCommand.PARAM_COMMAND + self.command # not sure if apikey has to be sent as part of the URL if the request # is a POST request. Currently sending as part of the URL if not self.apikey==None: uri += CBCommand.PARAM_APIKEY + self.apikey # if the method is GET, loop through all the parameters and # append to the URL. self.print_request_params() for key in self.request_params: value = self.request_params[key] if not value == None: uri += CBCommand.URI_SEPARATOR + key + '=' +str(self.request_params[key]) return uri; """ LOGIN COMMAND """ class CBLoginCommand(CBCommand): LOGIN_COMMAND = "login" def __init__(self, ipaddr, params): super(CBLoginCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBLoginCommand.LOGIN_COMMAND, None) self.set_request_params(params) self.set_method(CBCommand.METHOD_POST) def successCb(self): self.apikey = self.json_response.get('loginresponse').get('apiKey') LOG.debug(_("Login successful")) def failureCb(self): LOG.debug(_("Failed to login to CloudByte server")) """ LIST TSM COMMAND """ class CBListTsmCommand(CBCommand): LIST_TSM_COMMAND = "listTsm" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBListTsmCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBListTsmCommand.LIST_TSM_COMMAND, apikey) self.tsmid = '' self.iqn_prefix = '' self.poolid = '' self.iscsi_portal= '' self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): # Using the first available TSM to provision storage volume self.tsms=self.json_response.get('listTsmResponse').get('listTsm') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ ADD QoS GROUP COMMAND """ class CBAddQosGroupCommand(CBCommand): QOS_GROUP_COMMAND="addQosGroup" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBAddQosGroupCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBAddQosGroupCommand.QOS_GROUP_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.qosid=self.json_response.get('addqosgroupresponse').get('qosgroup').get('id') self.datasetid=self.json_response.get('addqosgroupresponse').get('qosgroup').get('parentid') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ ADD VOLUME COMMAND """ class CBAddVolume2Command(CBCommand): ADD_VOLUME2_COMMAND="addVolume2" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBAddVolume2Command, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBAddVolume2Command.ADD_VOLUME2_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.storageid=self.json_response.get('addvolumeresponse').get('storage').get('id') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ ADD ISCSI SERVICE COMMAND """ class CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand(CBCommand): ADD_VOLUME_ISCSI_SERVICE_COMMAND="addVolumeiSCSIService" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand.ADD_VOLUME_ISCSI_SERVICE_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.viscsiid=self.json_response.get('volumeiSCSIserviceresponse').get('viscsioptions').get('id') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ UPDATE CONTROLLER COMMAND """ class CBUpdateController(CBCommand): UPDATE_CONTROLLER_COMMAND="updateController" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBUpdateController, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBUpdateController.UPDATE_CONTROLLER_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ UPDATE QoS GROUP COMMAND """ class CBUpdateQosGroup(CBCommand): UPDATE_QOS_GROUP="updateQosGroup" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBUpdateQosGroup, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBUpdateQosGroup.UPDATE_QOS_GROUP, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ LIST FILE SYSTEM COMMAND """ class CBListFileSystem(CBCommand): LIST_FILE_SYSTEM="listFileSystem" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params, volume_name): super(CBListFileSystem, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBListFileSystem.LIST_FILE_SYSTEM, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) self.volume_name=volume_name def successCb(self): volumes=self.json_response.get("listFilesystemResponse").get("filesystem") for vol in volumes : if vol.get('name')==self.volume_name: self.qosid=vol.get("groupid") self.volumeid=vol.get("id") self.quotasize=vol.get("quota") self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ UPDATE FILE SYSTEM COMMAND """ class CBUpdateFileSystem(CBCommand): UPDATE_FILE_SYSTEM="updateFileSystem" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBUpdateFileSystem, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBUpdateFileSystem.UPDATE_FILE_SYSTEM, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ DELETE FILE SYSTEM COMMAND """ class CBDeleteFileSystem(CBCommand): DELETE_FILE_SYSTEM="deleteFileSystem" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBDeleteFileSystem, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBDeleteFileSystem.DELETE_FILE_SYSTEM, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ LIST ACCOUNTS COMMAND """ class CBListAccount2Command(CBCommand): LIST_ACCOUNT_COMMAND="listAccount2" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBListAccount2Command, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBListAccount2Command.LIST_ACCOUNT_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.accountlist=self.json_response.get("listAccountResponse").get("account") def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ SNAPSHOT CREATE COMMAND """ class CBCreateStorageSnapshot(CBCommand): CREATE_STORAGE_SNAPSHOT_COMMAND="createStorageSnapshot" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBCreateStorageSnapshot, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBCreateStorageSnapshot.CREATE_STORAGE_SNAPSHOT_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ LIST SNAPSHOTS COMMAND """ class CBListSnapshotsCommand(CBCommand): LIST_STORAGE_SNAPSHOT_COMMAND="listStorageSnapshots" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBListSnapshotsCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr,CBListSnapshotsCommand.LIST_STORAGE_SNAPSHOT_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.snapshots = self.json_response.get("listDatasetSnapshotsResponse").get("snapshot") self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ DELETE SNAPSHOT COMMAND """ class CBDeleteSnapshotCommand(CBCommand): DELETE_SNAPSHOT_COMMAND="deleteSnapshot" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBDeleteSnapshotCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr,CBDeleteSnapshotCommand.DELETE_SNAPSHOT_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE

commit_message:
Make install_venv.py executable.

Not sure why this script was not executable before.

Since it is to be used as an executable, add a shebang line
and chmod it +x.

Change-Id: Idb59b53c7ffeec96b49ecd8132c6469861adc143

commit_message:
Merge with Oslo (2548344)

Merge utils with current master (2548344)
from Oslo-incubator.

This brings, along other fixes, a lot of Hacking
related warning improvements that block cinder
from enabling gating on hacking related checks.

The list of commits included in this merge are:

    0bf03b7  Add network_utils.urlsplit
    15c17fb  Make lock_file_prefix optional
    1a2df89  Enable H302 hacking check
    1b076ed  Ensure install_venv works behind firewalls
    1dcc747  Fix stylistic problems with help text
    22ec8ff  Make AMQP based RPC consumer threads more robust
    27d4b41  Move synchronized body to a first-class function
    323e465  Add conditional exception reraise
    3243cdf  python3: handle module moves in log
    3948aee  Highlighting the deprecated nature of 'log-format'.
    67bd769  python3: Fix traceback while running python3
    7b7566b  Add netaddr.IPAddress support to to_primitive()
    8719d26  Don't attempt to patch eventlet without the patch
    90b6a65  Fix locking bug
    aa5b658  Allow passing a logging level to processutils.execute
    b21fc56  Fix bad default for show_deleted
    b41862d  Use param keyword for docstrings
    b873454  Added convenience APIs for lockutils
    c7c55b2  Improve usability when backdoor_port is nonzero
    cb2a2b6  Modify local.py to not be dependent on Eventlet
    d28fa69  python3: Add python3 compatibility.
    df3f2ba  BaseException.message is deprecated since Python 2.6
    e456727  Remove useless logging in networks_utils

Change-Id: I5af3be85cc97bf7cb3968cd544460df9e3fb9ca7

commit_message:
use XML serializer for account listings

And do a better job of preserving the old formatting this time, since
apparently not everyone can be bothered to just use a real XML parser.

Change-Id: Iaf82ee89989f96dc4cb689caf692cc24fe1c7b37

commit_message:
Use the lock decorator and close/join the thread pool

When the thread pool is owned by the engine (when it
is not passed in) we should be careful and ensure that
we close the pool (this stops it from accepting new
work) and then join on the pool (this ensures that all
contained threads complete) to avoid resource leakage.

Change-Id: Icb6e0f8051c017458657b4ff8872d3af44565c18
Fixes: bug 1221382

commit_message:
Fix error casting value to float in lvm.py

Special locale setting may result in that "vgs" command output different
results. Such as:

$ LC_NUMERIC='es_ES.UTF-8' sudo vgs
VG #PV #LV #SN Attr VSize VFree
vg_eharney 1 6 1 wz--n- 465,25g 12,97g

Fix bug 1219963

Change-Id: Ibe79d5ce673738d8e37f86de9106ab347c21bd52
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/30/45430/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note(haomai): Run command "sudo vgs" may output "12,97g" because of # special locale setting data['free_capacity_gb'] = float(self.vg.vg_free_space.replace(',', '.'))

commit_message:
Move dbinstance into a TemplateResource

The old dbinstance will soon be overtaken by the trove resource.
- The only reason for keeping this around is for people that don't
  have trove installed and want to use the AWS resource.
- Seperating it out into a TemplateResource really makes it easier
  for deployers and users to customise it.
- The old dbinstance did nothing "special" in python, and was really
  one of the first "TemplateResources" as it attempted to convert properties
  into parameters. Since this in now done a lot better in the TemplateResource
  lets just make use of that.

This will make it easier to migrate to other distros and versions.

Partial-Bug: #1215797
Change-Id: If72e1f40f67dc831551e0db8df8caaa002aaaeda
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/43/43643/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make global TemplateResources usable in the tests

At the moment we need the templates installed into /etc/heat/templates
and this is not very nice for the tests. So this patch
replaces "/etc/heat/templates" with the project's own template
path so we can at least test the api of the template resources.

Partial-Bug: #1215797
Change-Id: Ie4924b0358b97af8feaad93ed9187976b8932e3d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/84/45184/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make the new template validation usable from tests

This is so we can assert that new TemplateResources expose the
api that we are expecting.

Partial-Bug: #1215797
Change-Id: I6273f6e046bb7bd5e075e9190d8011af976573b8

added_lines: def _validate_against_facade(self, facade_cls): facade_schemata = properties.schemata(facade_cls.properties_schema) for n, fs in facade_schemata.items(): if fs.required and n not in self.properties_schema: msg = ("Required property %s for facade %s " "missing in provider") % (n, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) ps = self.properties_schema.get(n) if (n in self.properties_schema and (fs.type != ps.type)): # Type mismatch msg = ("Property %s type mismatch between facade %s (%s) " "and provider (%s)") % (n, self.type(), fs.type, ps.type) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) for n, ps in self.properties_schema.items(): if ps.required and n not in facade_schemata: # Required property for template not present in facade msg = ("Provider requires property %s " "unknown in facade %s") % (n, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) for attr in facade_cls.attributes_schema: if attr not in self.attributes_schema: msg = ("Attribute %s for facade %s " "missing in provider") % (attr, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) self._validate_against_facade(facade_cls)
deleted_lines: facade_schemata = properties.schemata(facade_cls.properties_schema) for n, fs in facade_schemata.items(): if fs.required and n not in self.properties_schema: msg = ("Required property %s for facade %s " "missing in provider") % (n, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) ps = self.properties_schema.get(n) if (n in self.properties_schema and (fs.type != ps.type)): # Type mismatch msg = ("Property %s type mismatch between facade %s (%s) " "and provider (%s)") % (n, self.type(), fs.type, ps.type) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) for n, ps in self.properties_schema.items(): if ps.required and n not in facade_schemata: # Required property for template not present in facade msg = ("Provider requires property %s " "unknown in facade %s") % (n, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) for attr in facade_cls.attributes_schema: if attr not in self.attributes_schema: msg = ("Attribute %s for facade %s " "missing in provider") % (attr, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg)

commit_message:
Prevents 400 NVP errors caused by a None display_name

The API forbids a resource name to be None, but the
Model does not. Such errors may  be induced by
programming directly against the plugin interface. With
this fix we avoid raising 400 faults which may be introduced
by involuntary programming errors.

Fixes bug 1221896

Change-Id: Ic1201c5af5691f2bed38753453f73c229858b10f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/85/45485/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Refactor finalize_put as an object method

Change-Id: Iec3f53c564505c29739bb5531a71a0a101f64193
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/57/45057/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _finalize_put(self, metadata, target_path): # Write the metadata before calling fsync() so that both data and # metadata are flushed to disk. write_metadata(self.fd, metadata) # We call fsync() before calling drop_cache() to lower the amount # of redundant work the drop cache code will perform on the pages # (now that after fsync the pages will be all clean). fsync(self.fd) # From the Department of the Redundancy Department, make sure # we call drop_cache() after fsync() to avoid redundant work # (pages all clean). drop_buffer_cache(self.fd, 0, self.upload_size) invalidate_hash(dirname(self.disk_file.datadir)) # After the rename completes, this object will be available for # other requests to reference. renamer(self.tmppath, target_path) hash_cleanup_listdir(self.disk_file.datadir) target_path = join(self.disk_file.datadir, timestamp + extension) self.threadpool.force_run_in_thread( self._finalize_put, metadata, target_path)
deleted_lines: def finalize_put(): # Write the metadata before calling fsync() so that both data and # metadata are flushed to disk. write_metadata(self.fd, metadata) # We call fsync() before calling drop_cache() to lower the amount # of redundant work the drop cache code will perform on the pages # (now that after fsync the pages will be all clean). fsync(self.fd) # From the Department of the Redundancy Department, make sure # we call drop_cache() after fsync() to avoid redundant work # (pages all clean). drop_buffer_cache(self.fd, 0, self.upload_size) invalidate_hash(dirname(self.disk_file.datadir)) # After the rename completes, this object will be available for # other requests to reference. renamer(self.tmppath, join(self.disk_file.datadir, timestamp + extension)) hash_cleanup_listdir(self.disk_file.datadir) self.threadpool.force_run_in_thread(finalize_put)

commit_message:
Load ML2 TypeDrivers in named order.

Similar to another bug on the MechanismDriver front, we need to specify the
stevedor parameter to load drivers in named order for ML2 TypeDrivers.

Fixes bug 1221781

Change-Id: Iacddf4c912bc5629172da7aaf9077e809a35e065
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/79/45479/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: invoke_on_load=True, name_order=True)

commit_message:
Allow uuid specification

When adding allow the api to take in the uuid
of the runner to be added, which maybe the task
uuid or another uuid. If not provided then the
runner will generate (and return) a new uuid.

This is useful to be able to tie into the resuming
system which goes by uuids, if the runner uuid is
different from the task uuid (which is acceptable
if the same task is added twice) then it becomes
hard to resume a dynamically changing uuid. This
change allows manual connection of the runner uuid
to the task which will ease resuming until we fix
how flows need to be able to save there runners
uuids (and structure).

Change-Id: I1634f76b04ab798d2902165d9845597618da92d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/12/43612/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def add(self, task, infer=True): r = utils.Runner(task)

commit_message:
Add a delete() method to DiskFile

In preparation for making the DiskFile class an abstraction layer for
the backend to all the object server REST API services, we add a
simple delete method which encapsulates the required behavior.

Change-Id: I539ad53c297e4c572e2f93c2524188fb89b2db40
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/86/44886/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def delete(self, timestamp): """ Simple short hand for marking an object as deleted. Provides a layer of abstraction. :param timestamp: time stamp to mark the object deleted at """ self.put_metadata({'X-Timestamp': timestamp}, tombstone=True)

commit_message:
Fix output of tools/validate.py --force

Previously:
Validation of all files and build of all books will be forced.

Following files will be validated:
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_compute-common.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-dashboard.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-keystone.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-neutron.xml
>>> doc/src/docbkx/basic-install/src/basic-install_controller-nova.xml
...

But that information is wrong since all files will get validated. Now
you get:
Validation of all files and build of all books will be forced.

Validating all files
file admin-guide-cloud/ch_networking.xml:
...

Change-Id: If07544f532bd6861a23f52aa7fda044d0673cccc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/91/45291/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if force: print("\nValidating all files") else: modified_files = get_modified_files() print("\nFollowing files will be validated:") for f in modified_files: print(">>> %s" % f) print("") modified_files = map(lambda x: os.path.abspath(x), modified_files)
deleted_lines: modified_files = get_modified_files() print("\nFollowing files will be validated:") for f in modified_files: print(">>> %s" % f) print("") modified_files = map(lambda x: os.path.abspath(x), modified_files)
